ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Theories of causation, and how that applies to legal cases and social sciences.

As the title suggests, the course provides an in-depth look at various types of explanatory relations, and applied the philosophical material in a very interesting way to legal issues, particularly focusing on discrimination. It was also an excellent introduction to what recent and semi-recent work in a lot of different areas of philosophy actually looks like.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are innumerable. One minor weakness (in my personal view): I think I would have appreciated getting a little more written feedback over the course of the term.

Strength: syllabus was thoughtfully crafted, professors Hu and Kohler-Hausmann are precise, lucid, funny, and make themselves available to meet with students.

Weakness: The final paper could be assigned with more detailed instructions, such as suggested essay prompts. I would have found these helpful, even if only to give me a sense of the kinds of questions the professors expected to be addressed in the final assignment.

PS: Look at the disclaimer given to students by the Registrar at the top of course evaluation forms: "As you evaluate your learning experience in this course, remember that everyone is influenced by unconscious bias. These subtle biases can be positive or negative. Please think carefully about your responses to this form."

This course was exceptionally well designed; the presentation of the material was very well thought out, the assignments were interesting and manageable, and the class meetings were very effective. The only area of possible improvement might be to provide students with more feedback on their work/contributions during the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes definitely, an interesting course on the intersection of philosophy and law.
One of the most exciting philosophy classes I've taken at Yale. Benefited a great deal from the electric combo of Profs Hu and Kohler-Hausmann.

I would recommend this course to any student, in particular students who are interested in getting a overview of what actually goes on in many different areas of philosophy, all while having the overarching structure of exploring explanatory relations.
